results.title: Frozen music
results.brief_description: This film is an examination of the thoughts and aspirations of the Victorian ruling class mentality as revealed through the Albert Memorial, a monument of pure signification. The soundtrack, composed by Michael Nyman, consists of a montage of voices, and is composed of Victorian quotations and modern analyses, together with the bemused speculation of a couple of American tourists.

results.title: Frozen II
results.creator_credit: Lisa Keene, Jennifer Lee, Chris Buck, Walt Disney Animation Studios and Walt Disney Pictures
results.brief_description: Elsa, Anna, Kristoff and Olaf head far into the forest to learn the truth about an ancient mystery of their kingdom.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lisa Keene, Jennifer Lee, Chris Buck, Walt Disney Animation Studios and Walt Disney Pictures
results.description:
Disney’s fierce princess sisters Elsa and Anna are back in the sequel to the worldwide phenomenon Frozen (2013). Three years after saving Arendelle from Elsa’s uncontrollable, arctic powers and proving the love of family can warm the coldest hearts, the sisters learn of an enchanted forest whose elemental spirits are accidentally awakened to wreak havoc on their kingdom. To once again save the day, Elsa and Anna embark on an epic journey with Kristoff, Olaf and Sven to uncover the source of Elsa’s powers and discover a devastating family secret.

Building on the $1.2 billion dollar success of the first film, Frozen II (2018) likewise avalanched across the globe. With all the main cast reprising their roles, including Idina Menzel and Kristen Bell, and featuring brand-new songs, Frozen II became the second highest-grossing animated feature in history, just behind Disney’s The Lion King (2019).

Charting the growth of the princesses from the first film, the character designers came up with new looks (as well as the technology to make them) to demonstrate their evolution. The concept art above is an early illustration of a key scene where Elsa hears the siren song of the enchanted forest calling to her. As she’s awoken in the middle of the night, Elsa wears an ethereal magenta nightgown and her iconic braid from the first film appears more casual – after all, she’s been asleep. Small details are important. In the first film, when Elsa retreated from the world, her hair was tightly confined to a bun until she “Let It Go”. Likewise, Elsa’s hair becomes freer as she discovers more about herself after the performance of “Into the Unknown” from this scene.
description_for_label:

results.title: Frozen gold of the Klondike
results.creator_credit: Christina L McCaughey, National Film Board of Canada and Film Factory
results.brief_description: A lively historical look at gold mining in the Klondike from gold-rush days to the present using archival stills and footage.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christina L McCaughey, National Film Board of Canada and Film Factory

results.title: Frozen asset
results.brief_description: The delicate and awe-inspiring environment of Antarctica is threatened by unrestricted tourism, oil and mineral exploration, and the competing territorial claims of several nations. The program explores several of the most pressing issues, including whaling, the inadequacies of the Antarctic Treaty, and the intended legitimisation of mining by the minerals convention.

results.title: Frozen
results.brief_description: Princess Anna dreams of finding true love at her sister Elsa’s coronation before fate takes her on a dangerous journey in an attempt to end the eternal winter that has fallen over the kingdom.

constellations_other.name: Stop-motion and animation superstars
constellations_other.description: Despite the ease of new technology and a legacy going back to the beginning of cinema, stop-motion animation techniques are as popular as ever.

results.description: Young princess Anna of Arendelle dreams about finding true love at her sister Elsa’s coronation. Fate takes her on a dangerous journey in an attempt to end the eternal winter that has fallen over the kingdom. She’s accompanied by ice delivery man Kristoff, his reindeer Sven, and snowman Olaf. On an adventure where she will find out what friendship, courage, family, and true love really means.

On an adventure where she will find out what friendship, courage, family, and true love really means.

results.title: Frost
results.creator_credit: J.A.D. Cartwright and Shell Film Unit
results.brief_description: Severe frosts coming in the late spring can create havoc in the orchard. Various ways of protecting fruit trees against frost damage have been tried. However, the best protection available at present is probably that derived from a knowledge of how cold air behaves; the orchard can then be planned so that the layer of cold air runs away from the orchard, and frost pockets are avoided.

results.title: Frontline. Series 2. One big family. Working class man. Divide the community, multiply the ratings. Changing the face of current affairs.
results.creator_credit: Rob Sitch, Jane Kennedy, Tom Gleisner, Santo Cilauro, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Frontline TV Prod
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Frontline”.
In “One big family” ratings are down but the new network promo takes first priority. Mike attempts to broaden his image by becoming a “Working class man.” The Frontline team are investigating ethnic violence in “Divide the community, multiply the ratings”. A consultant is called in to help ratings in “Changing the face of current affairs.”
results.title_for_label: Frontline. Series 2. One big family. Working class man. Divide the community, multiply the ratings. Changing the face of current affairs.

results.title: Frontline. Series 1. Playing the ego card. Add sex and stir. Smaller fish to fry. This night of nights
results.creator_credit: Rob Sitch, Jane Kennedy, Tom Gleisner, Santo Cilauro, Australian Broadcasting Commission and Frontline TV Prod
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Frontline”.
Four episodes from the highly acclaimed television series. In “Playing the ego card” Mike wants to boost his credibility and Brook wants the front desk. In “Add sex and stir” Mike has a busy time organising a party and the Frontline team stir up a hot story about lesbianism in sport. Will Mike stick to his guns in “Smaller fish to fry” when he investigates some top businessmen. “This night of nights” takes a look at the Logies.

results.title: Frontline. Series 1. Desert angel. The Siege. We ain't got dames.
results.creator_credit: Rob Sitch, Jane Kennedy, Tom Gleisner, Santo Cilauro, ABC-TV (Australia) and Frontline Television Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Frontline”.
Three episodes from the highly acclaimed Australian comedy show which exposes life behind the cameras of a popular current affairs program. A beautiful aid worker believed missing in the desert is found and the Frontline staff attempt to get an exclusive in “Desert angel.” Meanwhile, another network tries to poach legendary anchorman Mike Moore. A gunman takes several hostages in a remote farmhouse, and Frontline’s questionable methods to gain a scoop boosts their ratings in “The Siege.” Frontline tries to woo back female viewers by ditching their Friday night funnyman in “We ain’t got dames.”
results.title_for_label: Frontline. Series 1. Desert angel. The Siege. We ain’t got dames.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rob Sitch, Jane Kennedy, Tom Gleisner, Santo Cilauro, ABC-TV (Australia) and Frontline Television Productions

results.title: Frontline education kit No.2
results.creator_credit: Rob Sitch, Jane Kennedy, Tom Gleisner, Santo Cilauro, ABC-TV (Australia) and Frontline Television Productions
results.brief_description: This tape contains two episodes of the ‘Frontline’ series. ‘Heroes and villains’, tables turn when a book publishing company manipulates the media generally and Frontline in particular to portray a dull textbook as a racially potent controversy and gain publicity, the irony being that Mike Moore is more homophobic than the book’s author! ‘Keeping up appearances’, Mike has a P.R. nightmare: he’s the subject of a front cover story in the first issue of Brave - a new gay magazine. Jan’s efforts to change his image lands Mike in several ludicrous situations. On the other hand the plight of a disfigured prostitute is a public relations and ratings triumph for Frontline, though Brooke seems far more interested in her own appearance prior to a Lachlan Murdoch interview than with the woman’s facial injuries. Roleplay game “Newsflash” and “Frontline” script included.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rob Sitch, Jane Kennedy, Tom Gleisner, Santo Cilauro, ABC-TV (Australia) and Frontline Television Productions
